Do you remember Huwyd Larch?
Yes, he was with me.
He was on the road, he was a rockman, and he was working.
And we built this bridge.
And he said it was alright, that was quite good.
And then, I forget where the next one was, but I built quite a few in time.
Were bridges built before that George?
There was none.
The only one I know was in Blanglin and that was a stone arch bridge.
And that was the only one I can know of.
And when I started, the first little bridge I actually built was in Herman Valley to a holding.
Caipweth.
And the bridge had gone down to the holding.
And a lad came up from Corris.
A gang came up from Corris.
They each started showing me out of the standard bridge,
which was tram rails by the then, I don't know if they were tram rails from Liverpool.
And what was required and how to carry on.
And then I was left on my own then, I built this one in Llanes did.
Was that a tram rail one as well?
Yes, they were all tram rail ones till...
Well I can't remember the transition.
But you see there was a great panic because they were getting these tram rails from Liverpool.
And in fact I think some of the lads went there with machines to dig them up and bring them.
And we could do up to 30 feet span of tram rails.
And then one day, not here but somewhere, somebody dropped one and it snapped in half.
There was great panic then.
There was to be nothing more than 17 foot span.
So I had a good job then, all the bridges we built.
And there was some in Clacau, you know that I hadn't built tram rail bridges.
And there was one in Meysnwydian, just up from Meysnwydian to the right of the bridge.
And that was quite wide. We put a central pier under that.
We had to go there and halve the span.
And if the span was 18 feet, you put another foot on one of the...
I remember doing that. That was a nasty job.
Yeah, you had to do that.
And then they bought these, they were factory floor beams actually.
But the first pre-stressed beams I ever used was up in Harvard Lars.
There was a 30 foot span bridge there.
And they weighed a ton each.
But they were stuck in Shrewsbury for a long time, well one half of them,
because the trailer carried them, the tyres set on fire.
